title: 'Incredibly rare' Francois' langur monkey born at an Australian zoo
text:
One of the world's rarest monkeys has been born at an Australian zoo.

The male Francois' Langur, also known as Francois' leaf monkey, has distinctive orange fur, is one week old and has not yet been named.

Critically-endangered, the animal is only found wild in China and Vietnam, but it is threatened by poachers and loss of habitat in its home countries.

Keepers at the Taronga zoo in Sydney said it was 'incredibly rare' to see a baby Francois' langur.

There are thought to be only around 3,000 of the monkeys left in the wild. The adults, in contrast to their offspring, have black fur.

The week-old Francois' langur has not yet been named. He stands out because his fur is bright orange, compared to the black hair of his mother, Noel

'Seeing Francois' Langurs in the wild is incredibly rare, but seeing a baby is even more so,' said senior zookeeper, Jane Marshall.

The baby's bright orange hair will last just a couple more weeks before it begins to darken to the black fur its mother, Noel, has.

'It’s very interesting seeing the females in the group interact and care for the baby, Ms Marshall added.

'They all clearly care for him very much, and pass him to one another throughout the day.

'Not a lot of people know about Francois' Langurs as a species, but these beautiful animals are very vibrant animals, who are incredibly agile and intelligent.'

François’ Langurs live in groups of females called harems.

The adults in the group take turns looking after the babies, which helps the new mothers to cope with their duties while also letting others practise motherhood.

A newly-born male Francois' Langur, one of the world's rarest monkeys, staying close to his mother Noel at the Taronga Zoo in Sydney

The zoo has celebrated a birth of this rare species before when one of its other females, Meili, gave birth to Nangua in November 2015.

Noel, the new baby's mother, used to carry Nangua around about half of the time when he was newborn, the keepers said four years ago.

And now Noel has a baby of her own and the tables have turned, as other females in the group are helping to care for him.

Taronga Zoo is the only zoo in Australia to have a population of Francois’ Langurs. In the UK, babies have been born at Twycross Zoo in Leicestershire and zoos in Belfast and Kent.

The animals were once abundant in the Far East but, because of poaching, logging and building work destroying their habitats, have become endangered.

The International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has listed the species as endangered since 2008.
description: A Francois langur monkey baby has been born at Taronga Zoo in Sydney, the only zoo in Australia to have the monkeys. Native to China, they are now endangered because of poaching and logging.
